description:
Branchiostoma floridae, also known as the Florida lancelet or the American amphioxus, is a small, elongated marine invertebrate species belonging to the phylum Chordata, class Cephalochordata. It is found in shallow waters along the coasts of the Atlantic Ocean, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea.

The Florida lancelet is a filter-feeding organism that lacks a true backbone, skull, and other distinct organs found in vertebrates. Instead, it possesses a notochord, a dorsal nerve cord, and a series of gill slits, which are characteristic features of chordates. It has a transparent, elongated body with a pointed head and a mouth surrounded by numerous cirri (tentacle-like structures) that help in feeding.

Branchiostoma floridae is a hermaphroditic species, meaning each individual possesses both male and female reproductive organs. Reproduction occurs through the release of gametes (sperm and eggs) into the water column, where external fertilization takes place. The resulting embryos develop into free-swimming larvae, which eventually settle and metamorphose into adult forms.

As a basal chordate, Branchiostoma floridae provides valuable insights into the evolutionary origins and relationships of vertebrates, making it an important model organism in developmental biology and comparative genomics research.
